user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_count_sem_prop_t *count_prop)
{
    int                                 sval;
    OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);

    if (sem_getvalue(&impl->id, &sval) < 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    /* put the info into the structure */
    count_prop->value = sval;
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_count_sem_table[OS_MAX_COUNT_SEMAPHORES]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
    int32     value;
} OS_count_sem_prop_t
...
typedef struct
{
    sem_t id;
} OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_SEM_FAILURE (-6)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No fragments in OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl modify a function parameter itself. The function parameters are: const OS_object_token_t *token and OS_count_sem_prop_t *count_prop. The code does not reassign either parameter (no statements like token = ... or count_prop = ...). The write to count_prop->value modifies the object pointed to by the pointer parameter, which is permitted by the rule (the pointer itself must not be modified, but the pointed-to object may be). The use of *token in the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro merely dereferences the token to index the object table and the macro takes the address of that dereferenced object; this does not reassign or modify the parameter token itself. All other operations (assigning to local variable impl, calling sem_getvalue with addresses of impl->id and local sval, returning status codes) operate on local variables or pointed-to objects and do not violate Rule 17.8. Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation for this rule.
